subtopic: WILD ANIMAL AND PLANT PROTECTION ACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I hope the parliamentary secretary, in his very articulate and wide-ranging intervention, will not get carried away by his own quotations in the assessment of this bill. We certainly welcome the introduction of this bill on this side of the House. After careful examination, we will co-operate for its speedy passage. We would like to bring the parliamentary secretary and the government back to earth as to what this particular bill will achieve. Instead of reading "an act respecting the protection of certain species of wild animals and plants", the bill should read "an act respecting the protection of certain species of wild animals and plants from trade". It is a trade oriented piece of legislation. Certainly it is needed, and brings us in line with the international community and with our commitments made under the CITES agreement of 1975. It will place Canada in a good light internationally.
It is a bill that will require witnesses to be heard at the committee stage. Game wardens and other officials with the Canadian Wildlife Service will probably make some pretty significant contributions to its implementation. I would also include the National Parks people in that. No doubt there is a very broad community that needs to be canvassed.
There is a potential sleeper in this issue and that is whether this bill will control the import of game species for game ranching. We have had an experience recently with imported elk with tuberculosis. The problems that have been created are well known. The government
March 17, 1992

needs to be alerted to this aspect of the bill for potential loopholes in its application.
The bill itself has very strong and desirable implementation features. It gives the minister certain powers to appoint officers who will have the role of justices of the peace to implement the legislation. We hope the government will make the necessary funds available. The offences described in the proposed bill are certainly commensurate with the damage that poachers and illegal importers and exporters are committing.
The point that needs to be made is the one I referred to at the beginning. While this bill is heavily oriented on the trade side in the control of imports and exports from Canada of flora and fauna that need protection, it has virtually no impact as proposed on the conservation and protection of endangered species domestically.
That aspect is not revealed in the title of the bill, and therefore has to be highlighted at this stage. It is still possible, when the bill is examined at the committee level, to introduce certain amendments that will permit the introduction of clauses that will allow Canadians in generations to come to enjoy certain species, both flora and fauna, that may be extinct unless something is done about it. That matter is extremely important domestically and transcends the preoccupation with trade which is emphasized in this particular bill.
I would like to bring to your attention a private member's bill introduced by the member for Davenport in May of last year on this subject. That act is entitled "an act respecting the protection and rehabilitation of endangered and threatened species". It is Bill C-209. It is waiting its turn to be debated. In that bill the member for Davenport, in a rather accurate manner, attempted to specify the purposes that need to be achieved in Canada to protect the endangered areas in both flora and fauna.
In Canada we need to identify, protect and rehabilitate flora and fauna threatened or endangered by human activity.
Second, we need to develop and implement programs to restore the populations of threatened and endangered species of flora and fauna to self-sustaining numbers. This is nothing particularly extravagant or unusual. It has
Government Orders
been said by a number of conservationists and people in this particular area.
This is what is missing in Bill C-42 which is preoccupied with trade, and quite rightly so. We do not object to that. On the contrary, we support that preoccupation and interest in the protection of the public interest in those terms. At the same time it lacks the conservationist approach for the species that need particular attention.
Since 1964 there has been a Wilderness Act in the United States under which certain areas can be identified and protected. These areas are generally endangered spaces which provide habitat for endangered species. It is regrettable that the government until now did not find the time to table complementary legislation for action of this nature in Canada.
The parliamentary secretary referred to the Wildlife Strategy for Canada which is a very fine document. It has all the right and appropriate words. Unfortunately it lacks an action plan. It fails to spell out the required timetable. It does not identify areas which are prime candidates for protection. It is a good statement of principle without a plan for implementation.
I would like to bring to the attention of the parliamentary secretary as forcefully as I can that C-42 will not provide protection to endangered species which are not threatened by international trade. In other words, it leaves out a fairly important sector.
We welcome the initiative because it is desirable and necessary, but its scope is too narrow. It leaves out too many species, both in terms of flora and fauna.
Finally , I would like to draw your attention to a fact the parliamentary secretary already alluded to in his concluding remarks. Legislation of this kind will be much more effective and achieve its desired goal if it is matched, accompanied and complemented by a very intensive public information and education program.
We really need to sensitize the public and our young people in particular. They are very receptive to flora, fauna and wildlife and particularly to the endangered side of it. We have to perform a very important role which only governments can perform on behalf of the public. We need an intensive campaign which will accelerate and perhaps make the success of Bill C-42 more readily possible.

March 17, 1992
Government Orders
Having said that, I really would like to congratulate the parliamentary secretary for having introduced this bill at this time.
I urge him to convince the minister that we now need a companion bill which will deal with the protection of endangered species which are not threatened by international trade.

subtopic: WILD ANIMAL AND PLANT PROTECTION ACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to have an opportunity to speak on Bill C-42, which as the parliamentary secretary and my friend from Davenport have already said, is a piece of legislation that is long overdue.
It is urgently required and certainly in terms of the essential principles, although I agree it is very narrow in scope, it is a piece of legislation worthy of support and quick passage. We should get it on to the legislative committee and back into the House.
I must point out at the beginning of my remarks that I regret this is not a piece of legislation that comes at the issue with an ecosystem approach. It is clearly crisis management legislation, and it is something that is becoming increasingly common in this Chamber and in chambers around the world, rather than moving forward with the ecosystem approach. This approach was well discussed and widely discussed in the development of the Brundtland commission report "Our Common Future".
We have to start with the title which regrettably is both inappropriate and misleading. It raises the hope among many Canadians that it deals specifically with the protection of endangered Canadian species and their habitat. In fact, it does no such thing.
The scope of the bill needs to be either massively increased so that it deals seriously with endangered species and endangered spaces in Canada, or there should be a parallel bill.
The title should read "an act respecting trade and transport of certain species of wild animals and plants", or it should read "an act respecting trade and traffic of certain species of wild animals and plants". As read at the moment, if someone were simply to read about it in the paper or a magazine article, one would think from
the title which says: "an act respecting the protection of certain species of wild animals and plants" that it is quite a wide bill.
In fact, it might be something like the 1973 legislation from the United States which has protected species as widely diverse as the snail darter or the spotted owl. Regrettably, this legislation is nowhere near that. I regret that it is being sold to a certain extent as that kind of broad-based protective legislation.
It does do three things. It protects some of Canada's wild animal and plant species from illegal trade. It protects some Canadian ecosystems from the introduction of designated, harmful species and it helps to protect wild animal and plant species in foreign countries from poaching and smuggling.
Therefore, it is sort of CITES plus some other species. When I say plus, it means that they are protected or are in need of protection in certain other countries. We are going to be able to assist some other countries that are faced with chronic poaching, smuggling and illicit trading in both plants and animals.
Oddly enough, our own endangered species have never been added to CITES. One really has to wonder after all of these years just how serious governments of Canada have been in protecting either endangered species or endangered spaces.
Right now CITES lists some 1,000 plants and animals in Appendix I, which is the strongest of the appendices. There are 48,000 species and subspecies listed in total. That, of course, is only a small fraction of the endangered species in the world now. It is estimated at 1,900 and as at the middle of this century we were only losing one major species per year.
That accelerated during the last decade to about about one per hour. Now people like Edward Osborne Wilson and other experts in the field of biodiversity think we may be losing as many as 10 an hour. A lot of that related to the dropping of the canopies of the tropical rain forests at the rate of about an acre a second.
Of course, we are not immune from that kind of loss of space either. We are losing an acre of forest every five seconds. So even as I speak here, many acres of Canadian forests, including Canadian rain forests, will disappear forever.
March 17, 1992

Of the 48,000 species and subspecies listed in CITES, some are very large chunks such as 15,000 species of orchids that are listed because of the phenomenal value in illegal and illicit trade in some plant species.
At the moment the Game Export Act, which is our present piece of legislation for dealing with some of these issues, can only deal with dead animals and fur.
One does not have to be a rocket scientist to figure out that it is not going to get us very far today in terms of the kinds of traffic and trade there is, such as from my home province and from yours, Mr. Speaker, in a point touched on by the member for Brandon-Souris, which is of black bear gall bladders, paws and other parts that are traded for vast sums of money, particularly to the Orient.
Big smuggling and trade is left wide open. This legislation, as I said, should go quickly to the legislative committee where witnesses expert in this field, World Wildlife, Canadian Nature Federation and others well aware of the international and national ramifications of such a bill can be heard.
In 1975, external affairs made regulations under the Export and Import Permits Act to allow us basic compliance with CITES, which is the internationally recognized legislation on international trade and endangered species. However, since then most of the other 112 signatory nations have introduced much better compliance and enforcement provisions than those held by Canada.
Canada has promised since 1987 to develop new legislation. Consultation with the provinces has gone on since 1982. For a full decade there have been discussions with the provinces and territories regarding the need for this kind of legislation.
The green plan wildlife component in 1990 called for the introduction during 1991 of "new legislation to attack poaching and illegal trading" of wild animals and plants and to "strengthen wildlife law enforcement" and special measures for the enforcement of federal wildlife legislation.
Bill C-42 was finally introduced November 7, 1991, a delay of four and one-half years since the government
Government Orders
had first indicated that this legislation was coming forward.
It cannot be described as a piece of legislation that has an enormous amount of cabinet or government-wide support, although there is enormous support for it across Canada among those who are aware of the reckless endangerment of species around the world due to trafficking.
There are some very serious problems with the bill that will have to be remedied in the legislative committee.
First, the title must be changed. It is clearly misleading and it would be inappropriate for a piece of legislation to pass with such a misleading title attached to it. As I have said, it should be changed to "an act respecting either the trade and transport or the trade and traffic of certain species of wild animals and plants".
In the definition section of the act the word "animal" is found. It must be expanded in definition to include those Canadian species presently covered by the Game Export Act. This may have been something that was simply forgotten as it was being drafted. Similarly, the word "plant" which is found in the definition section must be expanded to cover Canadian plants.
The bill contains powers to promulgate regulations. These, to as great a degree as possible, should be included now and provided at the legislative committee process.
We debated earlier today how inappropriate it is that Bill C-13 is rocketing through the House without having the 15 sections of regulations at least available for members to view. In a piece of legislation such as this, surely since there have been 10 years of consultations with the provinces and the territories and four and one-half years of drafting, one assumes that this government ought to be able to bring the regulations forward so that we can at least have a look at them in the legislative committee.
By the fall of 1990, there were 195 endangered species in Canada and that was a list prepared by COSEWIC, which is the Committee on the Status of Endangered Wildlife in Canada. We need an immediate parallel bill to be introduced to protect endangered plants and animals and spaces obviously. Or preferably, this bill

March 17, 1992
Government Orders
should be amended in definition and throughout to give life to Canada's federal constitutional authority for wildlife conservation.
That is a power interestingly enough which the present government was prepared to transfer away to the provinces in the recent federal constitutional package. The Standing Committee on Environment made it very clear that this would be an extremely, if not extraordinarily unwise position for the government to take, it being an existing federal power and authority.
We all know that fish swim between provinces and territories, migratory birds fly across provincial and territorial boundaries and there is a very clear and mandatory role for the federal government to pursue. There are the three heads of power, one of which should clearly be listed in the provisions of this bill. That is peace, order and good government. It is a constitutional footing that should be more regularly utilized to avoid court challenges. Similarly, the criminal law and trade and commerce should be utilized somewhat more strongly. I will come to that in a moment in terms of this legislation.
This opportunity should be utilized to enact the biological diversity bill taking a proactive approach to maintaining diversity as well as an endangered species act. It should be clearly enunciated where limited populations and/or limited habitat are threatened by any activity that steps will be taken to protect the ecosystem.
As the member for Davenport suggested yesterday in our debate on Bill C-13, if sustainable development is really believed in by the government as it is by the majority of Canadians, that kind of wording which was proposed on sustainable development should similarly be used within Bill C-42.
Canada has lost a number of species already to various causes and many more are now threatened. Many Canadians have been misled by the title of this bill and have falsely assumed that like the U.S. legislation that protected the snail darter or the spotted owl, this applies and it does not.
The U.S. law called the Endangered Species Act, the ESA, was passed 20 years ago by Congress in 1973. It is hard to find a school child anywhere in the United States who does not know about the ESA. It has been a useful
piece of legislation, although its funding has been blocked by such notoriously anti-environmental presidents as Bush and Reagan. Again, it is a narrow piece of legislation because it is almost entirely crisis management as opposed to dealing with ecosystems.
We should protect ecosystems and not just the species. That is why the campaigns that are being launched by many groups are based on the concept of endangered spaces. Otherwise, we get species ghettos or unfenced zoos where small numbers of endangered species manage to eke out a marginal existence.
Biodiversity is clearly preferable because the endan-germent of species must be anticipated and prevented. One of the few things that legislatures can actually do is to be proactive rather than reactionary which regrettably is not very successful.
Clause 13 requires a consequential amendment. I am surprised that it is not there already. That clause provides for search and seizure without warrant. I must say it is one of the few pieces of legislation that truly could require such a power.
I can think of a number of situations where enforcement officers involved in dealing with traffickers in endangered plants or animals could find themselves in a situation where they would have to utilize the power. But it is a power that has been found to be very open to abuse.
The only other place you find it in Canadian law is under the old 1978 firearms legislation, the famous old Bill C-51.
I know personally of cases where that search and seizure provision without warrant has been abused by enforcement officers.
One of the surer ways of clearing the mind of those who might want to abuse this power is to require a mandatory report to Parliament on an annual basis, giving all of the specifics of the case where a search and seizure without warrant was utilized. I know there will be a reporting procedure to the courts but that has proven in the past to be very inadequate. It depends on the judge, it depends on all kinds of things as to whether or not any kind of proper follow-up is made. I believe there must be a subsection 13(a) added or perhaps an entire new clause to require specific reporting on search and seizure without warrant.
March 17, 1992

Under the offence and punishment section I find it awesome that the fines proposed are so out of whack with what other departments and other countries have been doing.
Let me give some examples. Under the summary section, punishment is presently set at $10,000 and up to six months in jail, whereas in the United States precisely the same kind of offence carries for an individual a $100,000 fine, up to 12 months in jail, and if it is a corporate entity involved in illicit activities involving plants or animals, it is $200,000.
Indictably we find the same kind of discrepancy: $100,000 and five years under the proposed legislation. In the United States it is $250,000 for an individual or $500,000 for a corporation and five years in jail.
The department, the minister or the government might argue that the cumulative approach is there. If somebody has a whole bunch of animal parts or animals, a bunch of black footed ferrets or other species, then the fine would apply seriatim to each of those. But the fact of the matter is that in the majority of cases one looks into, that is not an effective way to go about it because the courts rarely utilize that kind of consequential fine.
Even in our own National Parks Act which this House recently amended, the fine for poaching threatened species is $150,000 under the summary section and $150,000 and six months in jail indictably. It is very clear. Even if one looks at the Fisheries Act, it is now $100,000 summary or $500,000 and two years in the slammer indictably. Even in Alberta where poaching has become a very serious problem it is set at $100,000.
Bill C-42 must be amended in this clause. The clause on individuals should be set to $100,000, indictably to $250,000 or higher, and a new corporate clause must be included because trafficking in plants and animals is clearly on the rise. It is becoming a much more serious problem and it is quite often dealt with by corporate entities because to traffic efficiently and effectively in extremely highly valued plants or animals requires that kind of corporate structure. I believe that should be introduced and set at least at $200,000 so that we do not become what might be described as a point of entry.
Government Orders
The parliamentary secretary himself said that Canada could be used as a point of transit for trafficking. Of course that is what we are becoming right now because we have almost no legislation in this field. It is basically vacant other than the 1975 action by External Affairs and the Game Export Act.
The issue in terms of fines is very important. International traffickers look at North America as a large market for endangered plants and animals because people like for whatever reasons the exotic. It is very important that we not have the United States, the great republic to the south of us, with fines set at $100,000 and $200,000 for almost any of the offences and Canada at $10,000.
If you are a smuggler, Mr. Speaker-and I am not suggesting you are-which country would you want to come into? Would it be a country with a $10,000 fine or a country with a $200,000 fine? I would suggest that as a good smuggler you would choose Canada as a point of entry for your smuggling purposes. I do not think we should allow that. When one looks at the rate of species lost, as I said the time clock is accelerating exponentially. We used to lose a species a year. Then it went to a species an hour. Now it is at least 10 an hour.
We need some crisis management legislation, but let us at least make it effective. We can expand this bill so that it covers the waterfront and in fact deals effectively with what Canadians also want, which is protection for endangered species in our own country.
Finally, on the corporate section that should be included, it should be set at least at $200,000 with six months in jail and $500,000 with five years in jail when proceeded with indictably, simply to bring it into the context of other existing Canadian legislation and legislation in the United States. This problem is just like the drug trade. There are enormous profits to be reaped from going and getting snakes, bugs, monkeys, parrots or orchids from all around the planet. One of the major market zones is in our own country and another is in the United States.
If we are to have legislation that works, let us do it quickly and let us do it at the legislative committee. We are going to need more dough too. I note that there is $12.3 million under the green plan, but that only provides 29 new person-years over the next six years. I do not think 29 men and women being added over the next

March 17, 1992

six years will be able to do the job. We are going to have to do something more in that area too.

subtopic: WILD ANIMAL AND PLANT PROTECTION ACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have just a few words concerning this legislation and I give them after listening to the hon. member for Davenport.
The bill before the House is entitled an act respecting the protection of certain species of wild animals and plants. Then it says the act of Parliament which will come from this legislation will be called the Wild Animal and Plant Protection Act.
That is fine. If we could take the name of the legislation at its word it is an excellent piece of legislation, but we cannot. This does not cover what people would think it would cover if they read the title of the legislation, as the member for Davenport pointed out.
What does it cover? It covers all animals and plants listed under fauna in the appendix to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora signed on March 3,1973 in Washington, D.C.
The legislation limits the protection of endangered species. It gives the government the power to enforce a law only on an endangered species listed in the appendix to the convention. In other words, it would enable an enforcement officer to go into somebody's house without a warrant, as is listed under section 487 of the Criminal Code, only if the enforcement officer believes that in that dwelling or in that truck or car there is a portion of an endangered species and only if it is listed in the appendix to the convention.
In other words, there are three species of seals listed in appendix III of the convention. But the Pine Martin is not listed. That is an endangered species in the province of Newfoundland. If portions of those three particular seals listed in appendix III to the convention are to be found on somebody's property then the enforcement officer has the power under the act, but if an endangered species in Canada is in somebody's possession it does not give the enforcement officer the same authority.
The legislation, as the member for Davenport has pointed out, is an opportunity for the Government of Canada to spread the net even further. It gives it the
opportunity to be able to cover the endangered species. The animals are listed under fauna in the convention. It gives the government the opportunity to do what the Canadian Wildlife Service has wanted it to do for years. This is the vehicle. If the government saw fit, all it would have to do is go to Bill C-209 which is before this Chamber in the name of the hon. member for Davenport and incorporate it into this legislation. Then it would have a complete piece of legislation, not just a partial piece of legislation that to the objective viewer would seem rather limited and restricted in its character and certainly not as serving the wishes the Canadian Wildlife Service as I see them and as we should be serving those wishes.

subtopic: WILD ANIMAL AND PLANT PROTECTION ACT
speechtext:
I will be brief, Mr. Speaker. I too want to voice my support for this bill and the work that the member for Davenport has done on it.
I want to refer in my remarks specifically to a scientific American journal of September 1989 entitled "Managing the Planet Earth". In this particular journal there is an article on threats to bio-diversity. As I was reading this a few months ago I noticed a paragraph which I think is extremely relevant to the bill we are discussing today. I would like to read directly from it:
Wild plant and animal species also represent vast reservoirs of such
potentially valuable products as fibres and petroleum substitutes. One
example is the "babassu palm".
Then it goes on to explain that and says:
Another striking example is the rosy periwinkle.
People sometimes wonder why we are so adamant in trying to preserve these wild plants. It continues:
-rosy periwinkle is otherwise known as Catharanthus roseus, an inconspicuous little plant that originated in Madagascar. It yields two alkaloids, vinblastine and vincristine, that are extremely effective against Hodgkin's disease and acute lymphocytic leukemia. The income from these two substances alone exceeds $100 million a year.
On it goes. There is also a Thomas Eisner at Cornell University who has suggested, in addition to the compilation of biological inventories, that:
-programs should be established to promote chemical prospecting around the world as part of the search for new products. The U.S. National Cancer Institute has begun to do just that: their natural products branch is currently screening some 10,000 substances a year for activity against cancer cells and the AIDS virus.

Madam Speaker, last Friday evening a masked man entered the Steeles Bakery in North York demanding money.

*
Mr. Gardner, vice-chairman of the Metro Toronto Police Services Board, was granted a special protectionof-life permit to carry a handgun by the OPP five years ago. This was after his life was threatened.
Mr. Gardner drew his gun and ran into the store where he saw the 70-year old woman staggering and grabbing her chest. The masked robber thrust the cash drawer toward Mr. Gardner and started to run toward him shouting: "Go ahead and shoot me".

Madam Speaker, the world is well aware of the plight of the Vietnamese refugees in Hong Kong.
They are trapped in a refugee camp where the living conditions are horrible. They are trapped there by an agreement called the comprehensive plan of action. It is signed by many countries, including Canada. It says that the Vietnamese must return to Vietnam. For many of the families that is unthinkable and worse than death itself.
One of those families belongs to Luong Nguyen whose brother, Dai Due, lives in my riding.
Luong Nguyen's family arrived in Hong Kong before the comprehensive plan of action was agreed upon. Their Winnipeg-based sponsorship was approved before the plan of action was signed.
As immigration lawyer David Matas put it: "It is gratuitous cruelty on such people to subject them to the plan after they arrived in Hong Kong". Moreover Matas adds, "These people have been duped by Canadian law into thinking they could have been sponsored" and that "the sponsors have equally been misled into believing a sponsorship was possible".
My plea to the government is simple. Help these people.

Madam Speaker, today is St. Patrick's Day. It is the anniversary of the death of St. Patrick and it is a day on which the Irish, and those who wish they were, celebrate being Irish.
Although historians are uncertain about precisely where St. Patrick was bom, one thing is certain, St. Patrick was an Italian. I know that some members will say: "There he goes again. He has kissed some kind of Italian version of the Blarney Stone".
I have checked the facts and history records that St. Patrick was the son of Calpumius, a Roman official in Britain. He was born about 389 A.D. and died around 461 A.D. History tells us that he was carried off by raiders at the age of 16 to pagan Ireland. It was there that he met his life-long friend, Shamus O'Nunziata, who travelled with St; Patrick to Rome in the year 432 when St. Patrick became a bishop.
Of course, the rest is history. O'Nunziata stayed in Rome, dropped the O from his name and St. Patrick returned to Ireland. Have you ever wondered why the Italian and Irish flags are virtually identical? Or why you see a shamrock on all Alfa Romeo cars? The moral of the story is that on St. Patrick's Day there is a little Irish in all of us.

Madam Speaker, I again rise to bring to the attention of the House the need to fully recognize for full veterans benefits the members of the Canadian Merchant Marine who served on the high seas during World War II.
My late uncle, Captain Ernest Shatford was one such man. From 1939 to 1945 he traversed the Atlantic Ocean many times, from Nova Scotia to Europe, from Newfoundland to the Caribbean. For six years, his life was on the line for Canada and for Canadians. Yet he died two years ago this week ineligible for long-term care in a veterans hospital.
Canada's merchant marine veterans should be eligible for all veterans benefits including full benefits under the Veterans Independence Program.
There should be a book of remembrance with the names of Canada's merchant mariners who gave their lives in the cause of Canada.
The Minister of Veterans Affairs should use his good office on behalf of the government of Canada to encourage the construction of a suitable memorial to honour the memory of Canada's merchant seamen.
These suggestions should not only be accepted by the government but accepted and implemented as soon as possible.

subtopic: TRIBUTE TO THE LATE ROGER LEMELIN
TRIBUTE TO THE LATE ROGER LEMELIN
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, Roger Lemelin is no more. Perhaps better than anyone else, he depicted our social history. It was therefore very natural for the people to recognize themselves in his books and television series.
A man of letters, he won all the awards and was the first writer from outside France to sit on the jury for the Goncourt Prize.
A man of action, he skilfully directed America's largest French-language daily for 10 years.
Roger Lemelin was also a great patriot. In his last editorial in La Presse, published in 1981, the author of the Plouffe family series wrote that in taking his positions, he always wanted a stronger, more united Canada where a French Quebec, with its wonderful distinctness, could enjoy the riches of the vast territory of Canada while strengthening its cultural identity as a young nation.
He told members of the Canadian Press in Toronto on May 2, 1979 that never did he think that he would stop being French and that he had fought for French culture all his life. "I am glad to be a French Canadian," he said.
On behalf of my party and myself and, I am sure, all members of this House, I would like to express to his widow and his whole family our admiration and our deeply felt condolences.

Gasohol is made by blending 10 per cent ethanol with 90 per cent gasoline. It actually produces more octane to car engines while producing less of the emissions that cause things like acid rain and the greenhouse effect.

The SAGITs have been operating and a very substantial group of Canadian businessmen and women have been involved in these negotiations very deeply, indeed. They have been a great help to us in terms of promoting this free trade agreement.

Madam Speaker, the minister knows perfectly well that consultations between business groups and, indeed, provincial governments is a far cry from keeping Canadians regularly and fully informed, as urged by the all-party committee.
What is this government's position on the North American free trade negotiations, on the dispute settlement mechanism, on content requirements, on a social and environmental charter? These are concrete issues that demand concrete answers from this government. Canadians have a right to know-

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: I think the question has been asked.

speakeroldname: Hon. William C. Winegard (Minister for Science):
speakerposition: Minister for Science
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, the hon. member knows very well that in any negotiations of this kind the general Canadian position is very clear. It is exactly the same thing here as it was in the free trade agreement with the United States. We want to do things that benefit the Canadian people. That is exactly what we are trying to do.
The hon. member knows very well that you do not negotiate a trade agreement in public. That would give away the Canadian position and put us behind the barrel. We believe we are doing a good job.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, my question is to the Minister of Forestry on this St. Patrick's day.
Before the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement began there was under the GATT system free entry for a very large percentage of lumber exports going into the United States. Now under the FTA, as the minister will know, softwood products from B.C., for example, face an import tariff of about 29.48 per cent. Since the situation is a direct result of the FTA, will the minister tell us why his government does not intend to use the Employment Support Act of 1971 to support displaced workers and companies under the present situation.

speakerposition: Minister of Forestry
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, my hon. friend is badly informed.
The countervail duty provision that was captured in the memorandum of understanding preceded the free trade agreement. It is actually a benefit to us to have a free trade agreement because it adds to the protection we have under GATT. Nothing has changed there. An appeal has been launched with GATT.
The problem with GATT is that any decision by a GATT panel is not binding. There is a decision of a bilateral, independent dispute mechanism and a panel associated with that will be binding. The free trade agreement will be the instrument that will be used to vindicate our position.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I may suggest to the minister who just spoke that this will be an interim measure. There were 21,944 Canadian jobs saved as a result of the Employment Support Act of 1971. The cost of saving each job was only $903.77.
Last Tuesday the minister of industry said that this act was being considered. Last Thursday the minister for small business said that the act was not going to be considered. We know that there are applications in the minister's office waiting for the hearing.
My question is to the Solicitor General. Will he please advise his colleagues that they do not have the luxury of choosing whether to use the act or not to use the act.


March 17, 1992

Oral Questions
They must use the legislation in place. How long will it take to have these applications heard and how long will it take to have the 25,000 jobs in the softwood lumber industry in Canada protected?

speakerposition: Minister of Forestry
speechtext:
The question is a bit confusing. In 1971 when this act was used we did not have the same protection under GATT. Nor did we have a free trade agreement with an independent judicial tribunal made up of Canadian and American adjudicators who will be dealing with this issue.
I also want to point out to my friend that what we have is a preliminary hearing or a preliminary determination and that there are two more steps in the current round of assessing the legitimacy of the countervail duty actions, after which we will have access to article 19 of the free trade agreement. This is the best protection that we could possibly have in the situation.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext: Madam Speaker, my question is for the Minister of National Health and Welfare. Yesterday, the minister gave contradictory answers on the subject of breast implants, saying on the one hand that the documents were available but on the other that some were secret. Can the minister assure Canadian women that if the documents are available, he will make them public today?

speakeroldname: Hon. Benoit Bouchard (Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext: Madam Speaker, I much appreciate the question raised by the hon. member for Halifax, since I am asking for permission to table in the House a letter that I sent today to the chair of the House committee on the Status of Women, in which I tell her that we will make available to the committee 10,000 pages of documents on past or present studies done by the department or other bodies that we are asking the committee to consider and to be able to use all the required information, as I said yesterday, since neither I nor the department has anything to hide. This again should reassure women about breast implants.

Madam Speaker, I thank the minister for his response.
I would ask if he would also provide to this House a compendium of all the studies on breast implants in the possession of his department so that those could be looked at as well to ensure, as he has said today, that the women of Canada who wish to have breast implants can then make an informed consent.
Hon. Benoit Bouchard (Minister of National Health
and Welfare): Madam Speaker, all those documents that I released or pointed out to the committee exist today are documents which I can produce.
Of course, we have documents which are under what we call commercial confidentiality. If the member wants through the Department of National Health and Welfare to address any kind of request to the companies and they agree to release the documents, of course it will be a pleasure to do that.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Finance.
Canadians will be shocked to learn that this government has found another $30 million, which makes a total of $50 million, for the Canada 125 Corporation, none of which is allocated for community groups to celebrate Canada's 125th birthday.
In view of the minister's and the government's promised fiscal restraint, will the minister explain why this inefficient private corporation is accountable to no one, received an extra $30 million, a 150 per cent increase, when the same moneys would have paid for 10 years of the Court Challenges Program or five years of co-op housing?

speakeroldname: Hon. Robert de Cotret (Secretary of State of Canada):
speakerposition: Secretary of State of Canada
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, it has always been agreed with the Canada 125 Corporation, a private corporation subsidized by the federal government, that it would have a budget of $50 million: $12 million this year, $18 million for the next fiscal year and the rest for the third year.

March 17, 1992
Oral Questions
The corporation works with a board of directors that well represents all of Canada. It has already approved about 30 projects showing what Canadians have done in the past 125 years. I think that it works very well and I and the government are working with the corporation.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I have a supplementary for the Prime Minister or his Irish friend on his right, the Minister of Finance.
Will he confirm that his government will add a cost of living allowance to the salaries of Canadian judges which I calculate will cost $10 million additional next year? Will he tell the House why he is increasing the wages of judges who already make over $147,000 per year when, out of the same moneys, the government could fund a Court Challenges Program for five years? Does his government have any priorities?

speakeroldname: Hon. Harvie Andre (Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext: Madam Speaker, I believe that question anticipates an Order of the Day as the Judges Act is currently before the House.

speechtext: Madam Speaker, my question is for the Minister of National Health and Welfare. The National Drug Strategy expires at the end of March. Will the government be renewing it and when will we know?

speakeroldname: Hon. Benoit Bouchard (Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
I thank the member for the very intelligent question, Madam Speaker. A very brief question and the answer will be brief.
We are working on the file on the drug strategy and I am looking forward to being able to make an announcement soon.

speakerposition: subtopic
Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Liberal Party
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, my question is directed to the Prime Minister.
Because of his government's economic policies, Montreal faces losing another 250 jobs, this time at CP Rail. More than 1,000 jobs were eliminated in the railway sector since the beginning of this year, in a city where one out of every two adults is out of work.
When will the government start taking poverty in Montreal seriously and implement a genuine recovery plan to provide real jobs for people in Montreal who really need them?
Hon. Benoit Bouchard (Minister of National Health
and Welfare): Madam Speaker, the hon. member must know that recently the federal government announced a number of agreements on industrial development and tourism, especially for the Montreal area. We are now negotiating a very substantial announcement for the Montreal area with the Government of Quebec.
We have had astonishing results with our programs for east and southwest Montreal. In fact, the federal government has done a great deal for the Montreal area and intends to go on doing so in order to meet the specific needs of Montreal's community.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Liberal Party
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, the minister makes announcements but ignores the fact that every day we read announcements that hundreds more jobs will be lost in Montreal.

In only two years, 28 per cent of the jobs in the Montreal manufacturing sector have been lost. The real question is when are you going to introduce a policy that really creates jobs and not just gunsmoke, saying that you are announcing a program when every day we are losing jobs? When are you going to announce a real program?

speakeroldname: Hon. Benoit Bouchard (Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I would appreciate if, with honesty, the member would say all the jobs which were created in Montreal. He knows very well that in the aerospace industry, the telecommunications industry,
March 17, 1992

the pharmaceutical industry and in many other sectors we have created a lot of jobs in Montreal. I know very well that it is not very interesting for the opposition to say this government works well in Montreal.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, my question is for the Prime Minister. The Preston area of Nova Scotia dates as the oldest permanent black settlement in Canada with the East Lake section of that community being the most probable terminal for the black underground railroad. Yet, this very site has now been designated as a regional garbage dump, outraging both black and non-black Nova Scotians.
Will the Prime Minister ask officials from Parks Canada Historical Sites to immediately assess the site and have it recognized and protected as a site of national historical significance?

speakeroldname: Mr. Lee Clark (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of the Environment):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of the Environment
speechtext: Madam Speaker, as you know, we have a National Historic Sites Board whose responsibility it is to advise the Minister of the Environment and through the Minister of the Environment, Parks Canada, with respect to the designation of all historic sites, regardless of where they may be located in Canada. Certainly, on behalf of the hon. member, I will draw his concern to the attention of the historic sites board.

My supplementary question is to the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister, almost more than any other member of the front bench, is fully aware that the establishment of a garbage dump in a black community on a historically significant site will push back race relations in the province of Nova Scotia at least a decade.
What role is the Prime Minister or his ministers prepared to play to ensure that this issue does not further aggravate the already delicate state of race relations in the province of Nova Scotia?

speakeroldname: Mr. Lee Clark (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of the Environment):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of the Environment
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I understand that the site in question is located within very close proximity of the metropolitan authority which has the responsibility
Oral Questions
for municipal government in that area. There may well be a possibility that this does indeed fall into their jurisdiction.
In essence, I would repeat the answer I gave just a moment ago, that certainly the federal government through the National Historic Sites Board has a very keen interest in any area of potential national historical significance.
I have spent most of my life as an historian and I am very much aware of that. As I said before, I will ensure that the matter is brought to the attention of the National Historic Sites Board.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
My question is for the Minister of Employment and Immigration.
The Ottawa Citizen reports today that a former member of the Immigration and Refugee Board claims that "the Immigration and Refugee Board has become a wretched monster that is out of control".
Canada, as a signatory to the UN Convention on the Protection of Refugees, agreed that all persons with a well-founded fear of persecution have a right to protection from forced return to their country. Yet, Canada's over-all acceptance rate for refugee claimants went down from 76 per cent in 1989 to 64 per cent in 1991.
Will the minister, in view of many recent criticisms of the IRB, respond to the request of the Canadian Council for Refugees by appointing an independent, impartial investigation of its treatment of people claiming asylum in Canada?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speakerposition: Minister of Employment and Immigration
speechtext:
No, Mr. Speaker, I will not. I intend rather to make sure that the IRB can continue its good work on behalf of Canadians.
No country in the world has a better record than Canada in protecting genuine refugees. If the hon. member is concerned about the percentage, I remind him that Canada welcomed and gave protection to over
38,000	people last year. No country in the world equals that record. I think that we as Canadians can be proud of that.

March 17, 1992
Oral Questions

My question is whether the minister is trying to discontinue that record.
I have a further supplementary. Will the minister propose, as has been much asked for publicly, amendments to the Immigration Act to provide for a review of board decisions that are challenged?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speakerposition: Minister of Employment and Immigration
speechtext: Board decisions can now be challenged by appeal with leave to the Federal Court of Canada. That system is working well. But I have received representations from different groups. As we speak, my department is looking at ways of trying to improve the refugee determination system. Once we have conducted that review and consulted with members, we can then seize the government of proposals and make decisions at that time.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, in the absence of the Minister of Justice, my question is directed to the Prime Minister. Recently, the Minister of Justice received a letter from Mrs. Bertha Wilson, a retired judge of the Supreme Court of Canada, in which Mrs. Wilson expressed her consternation at the Conservative Government's decision to abolish the Court Challenges Program. She said the program was praiseworthy, imaginative and well managed.
At a time when Canadians are rethinking their Constitutional future, why should the government abolish a program that was seen as essential to making the courts accessible for women, aboriginal people, racial minorities, language and ethnic groups-all of whom know rights are an illusion unless they can go to court to defend those rights? How will the Prime Minister bring this program back?

speakeroldname: Hon. Gerry Weiner (Minister of Multiculturalism and Citizenship):
speakerposition: Minister of Multiculturalism and Citizenship
speechtext: I agree with everything the hon. member said, Madam Speaker. This program was very beneficial, but after nearly 300 cases, according to my information, we have now created a certain body of jurisprudence. That is what the program was for, and it was not necessarily meant to be in place for another 10 years.

Madam Speaker, my question is for the Acting Minister of Justice. It also concerns the Court Challenges Program.
The minister has suggested that this kind of program could be handled by the government itself. In this case the government would find itself challenging and defending the law at the same time. This would obviously be a conflict of interest for the government.
How exactly does the minister propose to deal with this problem?

speakeroldname: Hon. Gerry Weiner (Minister of Multiculturalism and Citizenship):
speakerposition: Minister of Multiculturalism and Citizenship
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, as I said, the Court Challenges Program was an excellent program, a made in Canada initiative, to really examine the laws for their fairness, the equality in language laws that were in place. It has done that very fairly. But, after almost 300 cases of jurisprudence that have been established, one would imagine that we now have a significant volume of jurisprudence.
Whether a program must go on forever should be determined now either by other jurisdictions which have a responsibility, or by the private sector, if there is such an interest.

speakerposition: subtopic
Deputy Whip of the N.D.P.
speechtext:
The federal government is pulling out of the Fraser River debris control program at the same time it is hosting in Vancouver the Environment '92 conference and at the same time it plans to announce the Fraser River Basin Protection Program agreement between the federal, provincial and municipal governments.
My question is to the parliamentary secretary for the environment. How can the government rationalize abandoning this critical debris control program in less than two weeks in light of its anticipated Fraser River protection program announcement?

speakeroldname: Mr. Lee Clark (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of the Environment):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of the Environment
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, as you know, the federal government announced in one of approximately 50 initiatives under the green plan, that it would be

providing $100 million to the clean-up of the Fraser River several months ago.
I understand that there may be an additional announcement, although it does not come under the jurisdiction of the Minister of the Environment, during the course of the next few days but I think you can appreciate, Madam Speaker, that it would never be politically wise for a parliamentary secretary to upstage any minister in making such an announcement.

speakerposition: subtopic
Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: I draw the attention of hon. members to the presence in the gallery of the Standing Committee on Consumer Affairs and Government Administration from Norway.
Hear, hear.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, during Question Period I raised a question with reference to judges' salaries as opposed to cutting the Court Challenges Program, the increase in salaries versus the cutting.
The minister stood up and said he could not answer the question because there was a bill before the House of Commons.
I would like clarification on this matter. I draw your attention to Beauchesne's, page 132, of the fifth edition, and I quote:
(12) Questions should not anticipate a debate scheduled for the
day, but should be reserved for the debate.
Likewise, in the new edition of Beauchesne's, the sixth edition, page 121, it states:
(12) Questions should not anticipate a debate scheduled for the
day, but should be reserved for the debate.
We are not debating the judges' salary bill today. We are debating an environmental bill. Does that mean we cannot ask questions on the general environment, that we cannot ask questions on pensions because there is a pension bill somewhere in the works of the House of Commons?
Point of Order
With respect, Madam Speaker, I would like a ruling on this. I believe that the minister was wrong and that he should have answered my question. He used the wrong way of ducking a good question.

speakeroldname: Hon. Harvie Andre (Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, we can certainly have a debate about whether that was a good question or not.
Quite frankly, the provisions of Beauchesne's and the experience of the House is that when a bill is before the House, it will come up for debate and that is the proper time for members on all sides to express their opinion and to vote on it.
The use of Question Period to engage in debate which can merely be repetition of what will come later while the bill is under discussion is an abuse of Question Period.
Finally I would remind the hon. member that there is no requirement that any question be answered. So the point of order-
Shame, shame.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: Order, please. The hon. minister.

speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, it is also out of order to shout down the person trying to address the Chair.
There is no requirement that in fact an answer be provided to any question. Therefore, it is not in order to raise as a point of order an objection to the answer to a question that he received during Question Period. He may not have liked the answer but that is the way it goes. You do not always get the answer you want.

Madam Speaker, with all due respect to the government House leader, the fact of the matter is that he did seek to hide behind procedure or, to put it more charitably, use a procedural argument in order not to answer the question of the hon. member for Port Moody-Coquitlam.
If he is able to do that without the Chair saying something to the contrary then that would set, in my judgment and I am sure the judgment of many other members, a very new precedent, a very new rule with respect to Question Period. To this point the rules are quite clear that questions cannot anticipate an Order of the Day.

March 17, 1992
Point of Order
I would ask you, Madam Speaker-

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext:
If I may, I have listened very carefully to the hon. member for Port Moody-Coquitlam, to the hon. member for Winnipeg Transcona and to the minister.
At that point in time in Question Period when the minister answered that the subject would be coming up for debate, as you know at any time the government can change whatever is being-
Oh, oh.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext:
The government can change the Order of the Day. The Speaker could not know whether this had been changed for later on this afternoon so I could not in any way judge the hon. minister's answer.
On the other hand as the minister did say, and on this point I think we will all agree, a minister is not obliged to answer a question. But I do agree with the hon. member for Winnipeg Transcona and with the hon. member for Port Moody-Coquitlam that Beauchesne's does say that when it is something that is to be debated later on in the same day, but I could not presume what would happen at the time.
I think tomorrow will be another day for Question Period. I would like us to proceed with the business before the House.
I rise on a point of order, Madam Speaker.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: Is this on the same point of order?
Yes.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: I think that all that can be said about it right now has been said.
Point of order.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext:
I beg your pardon. I do not understand, even though this is St. Patrick's Day, the reason to scream at the Speaker. I will not allow this in the House. My respect for this House and for this institution is obviously higher than what some members would like it to be.
I will listen to the hon. member for Churchill, but I do hope that he will keep his voice down.

Madam Speaker, I apologize for shouting, but you had cut off debate. I think this is a very important item and I had stood quietly three times previously on it. In your last intervention you said that there was no way of knowing what was coming up today in debate.
In fact prior to the lunch break a House order was passed saying that we would be dealing with third reading of Bill C-13 on the environment. That was a House order agreed to by all the parties.
We knew that the question raised by the member from B.C. was completely in order. We know what questions we are going to ask during Question Period. We know what the issues of debate were. The member had a completely appropriate question. He made a request, which was to have the Speaker rule on whether or not an issue could be raised in the House. Just because there is a bill which may come up one month, two months or three months hence-
Or never.

-or never, as my colleague from Mackenzie said, does not mean that the minister can refuse to answer a question.
We have to be in a position to be able to ask questions. Just because there may be legislation or may not be legislation before this House should not prevent that from happening.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext:
I am quite ready to listen to members all afternoon if they want. What I do not understand from the hon. member for Churchill is that I did agree with him. I did say that Beauchesne's says that we cannot anticipate something which will be debated today. I admitted not knowing what was the subject to be debated after the vote this afternoon. I do apologize. I was not in front of my television set, nor was I in the House of Commons, when the motion was passed earlier today. I had some other business to attend to.
I did agree with the hon. member. I really do not see where we are going now and what are the benefits of going on with this point of order. I would much rather the House proceed with the vote as it is expected and then we go on to debate the third reading of Bill C-13.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I listened with great interest to your
March 17, 1992

intervention. I concur that you have agreed with my colleagues from the New Democratic Party.
From time to time all of us may make a mistake, but I do want to raise with the Chair for possible reflection at another time that the question put by the hon. member for Port Moody-Coquitlam was a supplementary question, and the supplementary question I believe was on an entirely different matter as I understood it.
No.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext:
The hon. member says no, but perhaps the Chair might want to take that under advisement to see whether or not that was the actual case.
In terms of asking questions on the subject matter which may or may not be before the House, I would hope that the Chair would always give the benefit of the doubt in circumstances such as that to the questioner in that particular case.

Madam Speaker, I would just like to say that you have done an admirable job of pointing out where you yourself were in error, and we all respect you for having done that.
What we are seeking is some statement on your part about the extent to which the government House leader was in error in wrongly citing this procedure as a reason for not answering the question.
You said that the minister is not obliged to answer the question. That is true, but the minister is obliged to either not answer the question or, if he wants to give a reason for not answering the question, to give a reason that is true to the rules of the House and not something which distorts the rules of the House. That is what we want the Chair to say.
Until the Chair says that, that particular sentence by the government House leader stands and stands as a bad precedent and a precedent which distorts the rules of the House. We want the Chair to say otherwise, Madam Speaker.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: I do not see why this hon. member would raise his voice to me.

Don't take it personally.
Point of Order

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: I do not see what mistake I have made apart from not knowing that a motion had been passed earlier this day. Even at that, the government could have changed its mind.
But there was a mistake.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext:
You may not agree with the minister's answer and that is the hon. member's prerogative. I fully agree with that, but I did give the benefit of the doubt to the member, as the hon. member was suggesting, and I think that now we should proceed.
This point of order has to end at some point. There is nothing more that the Speaker can do at this time.
A point of order-

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: I have just said that to me this point of order has now been listened to very thoroughly and completely and there is no way that I can change anything at this time.
Let's go to the question.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext:
I think we will now go to the
question.
Point of order-

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: I would really ask that the hon. member find another way of wanting me to change whatever decision I have taken, which is no decision except to go to the question.
On a point of order, Madam Speaker-

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: I am listening to you.

Madam Speaker, I appreciate that you want to get on with House business and I appreciate that you heard my point of order. As you know, we are not yelling and so on. We both appreciate that the Speaker is the servant of the House.
We are concerned with some perhaps bad procedure. We think that the minister could simply have said: I am not going to answer your question or some other answer, but instead he raised a technical point that we think is against the orders of the House.
We would ask the Chair and other members of the House to reflect on that, and I will raise this again tomorrow after Question Privilege as a matter of privilege.
